docs.snippet: A cancer patient grapples with a failed crowdfunding campaign. And: a locker-room vigilante, roommates who can’t share everything and more.

headline.main: If You Love Me, Why Won’t You GoFundMe?

docs.snippet: The indictment secured by the special counsel makes it clear that Facebook was used extensively in the campaign to disrupt the 2016 election. How did Russia do it?

headline.main: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Russian Trolls’ Favorite Weapon

docs.snippet: A communication professor says social media should challenge the user’s beliefs rather than reinforce them.

headline.main: Facebook’s News Feed: Add Some Dissonance

docs.snippet: Why the internet is full of lies and why the problem isn’t getting fixed are big questions few in the tech industry seem eager to answer.

headline.print_headline: Dai and Jack’s Week in Tech: Don’t Trust the Internet
headline.main: Dai and Jack’s Week in Tech: Don’t Trust the Internet

docs.snippet: Officials from the judiciary and law enforcement are teaming up to try to prevent voters from being misled, arguing that freedom of speech cannot come at the cost of a tainted election.

headline.print_headline: Brazil Mounts a Campaign Against Fake News
headline.main: Brazil Looks to Crack Down on Fake News Ahead of Bitter Election

docs.snippet: With imperfect English and tireless posting on Facebook and Twitter, Russian trolls summoned Americans to rallies, praised Donald J. Trump and played on political divisions.

headline.print_headline: How Russians  Exploited Web In ’16 Meddling
headline.main: How Unwitting Americans Encountered Russian Operatives Online

docs.snippet: Millions of “bots” posing as real users are promoting celebrities, spreading misinformation and sowing discord. And it’s far easier to build a bot than to kill one.

headline.print_headline: How Lax Enforcement Breeds Impostors Online
headline.main: On Social Media, Lax Enforcement Lets Impostor Accounts Thrive

docs.snippet: We want to know more about our readers. Tell us about one thing in your life you’re super proud of.
The Facebook co-founder’s rise was meteoric. He argues that the same forces that helped him succeed have made it harder for others. In a new book, “Fair Shot,” he proposes a bold solution.

headline.print_headline: Inequality: A Secret  To His Success

docs.snippet: Twitter accounts suspected of having links to Russia were focused on Robert Mueller. But after news broke about the shooting, they quickly changed their focus.

headline.print_headline: Shots Are Fired, And Bots Swarm To Social Divides
headline.main: After Florida School Shooting, Russian ‘Bot’ Army Pounced
